Your honest heart of duty"The dominant note of characterization, 'duty,' is struck in the first line and surges in crescendo to be repeated five times in the last stanza." William B. Schurr, The Mystery of Iniquity, p. 35 [critical], Worden, So helped you that in fame you dwell; You bore the first iron battle's burden Sealed as in a diving-bell"In a poem published many years later, 'In a Church in Padua,' Melville describes the Roman Catholic confessional booth: "Dread diving-bell! In thee inurned/ What hollows the priest must sound,/ Descending into consciences/ Where more is hid than found." (William B. Shurr, The Mystery of Iniquity, p. 35) [intertextual; critical]. Alcides, groping into haunted hell To bring forth King Admetus' bride, Braved naught more vaguely direful and untried. What poet shall uplift his charm, Bold Sailor, to your height of daring, And interblend therewith the calm, And build a goodly style upon your bearing.
Escaped the gale of outer ocean— Cribbed"One must look to the major landmark of the history of this word in Macbeth. Macbeth has just experienced his first reversal: 'Most royal sir, Fleance is 'scaped.' Stunned by the implications, Macbeth replies "Then comes my fit again: I had else been perfect,/ Whole as the marble, founded as the rock,/ As broad and general as the casing air:/ But now I am cabin'd, cribb'd, confined, bound in/ To saucy doubts and fears." (III, iv; William B. Shurr, Mystery of Iniquity, p. 36) [Allusion, literary; critical] in a craft which like a log Was washed by every billow's motion— By night you heard of Og The huge; nor felt your courage clog

At tokens of his onset grim: You marked the sunk ship's flag-staff slim, Lit by her burning sister's heart; You marked, and mused: “Day brings the trial: Then be it proved if I have part With men whose manhood never took denial.”
A prayer went up—a champion's. Morning Beheld you in the Turret walled By adamant, where a spirit"The tutoring spirit, a monitor in another sense, must inspire ambiguous courage: it not only forewarns but *derides*." (Shurr, The Mystery of Iniquity, p. 36) [critical] forewarning And all-deriding"Derision, the cosmic laugh, is a spirit and therefore real and pervasive." (Schurr, The Mystery of Iniquity, p. 36) [critical] See "*Derision* stirs the deep abyss" in "The Conflict of Convictions." [intertextual] called: “Man, darest thou—desperate, unappalled— Be first to lock thee in the armored tower? I have thee now; and what the battle-hour To me shall bring—heed well—thou'lt share; This plot-work, planned to be the foeman's tenor, To thee may prove a goblin-snare"What Worden fins himself alone with is nothing less than the cosmic spirit of evil pervading and controlling the universe." (Schurr, The Mystery of Iniquity, p. 37) [critical] ; Its very strength and cunning—monstrous error!”
“Stand up, my heart; be strong; what matter If here thou seest thy welded tomb? And let huge Og with thunders batter— Duty be still my doom, Though drowning come in liquid gloom;
First duty, duty next, and duty last; Ay, Turret, rivet me here to duty fast!”— So nerved, you fought, wisely and well; And live, twice live in life and story; But over your Monitor dirges swell, In wind and wave that keep the rites of glory. C2
